block.p: Anti-Mine Group Accused Of Aiding Chechen Rebels Russia's domestic intelligence agency accused a British-based mine-clearing organization, Halo Trust, of providing military training and assistance to rebel forces. The organization denied that it had strayed beyond its humanitarian mandate to locate and clear minefields left over from the 1994-96 war in Chechnya.

The organization denied that it had strayed beyond its humanitarian mandate to locate and clear minefields left over from the 1994-96 war in Chechnya.

Theory on Concorde Crash French investigators said a piece of metal found on the runway probably caused a tire to blow out, sending debris into fuel tanks and sparking the fire that erupted as the Air France jet took off last month.

Plan to Meet Taiwan Leader Two congressmen, one a Republican and the other a Democrat, hope to meet with Taiwan's new president, Chen Shui-bian, during his overnight layover in California on Sunday, despite protests from China and warnings from the State Department that his visa precludes public events.

Venezuela President Visits Iraq President Hugo Chavez held talks with President Saddam Hussein in Baghdad, defying the United States by being the first head of state to go to Iraq since the Persian Gulf war in 1991.

Congress to Skip U.N. Meeting Organizers of a United Nations gathering to celebrate the growth and strengthening of national parliaments expressed chagrin that no one from the United States Congress seemed interested in coming to an event that will be attended by more than 170 speakers of legislatures around the world.

Egyptian Rights Activist Freed Saad Eddin Ibrahim, who has been under investigation for his pro-democracy projects, was released on bail after being held in prison near Cairo for 45 days without charges.

10 Killed in Kashmir Blast A car bomb exploded in Srinagar, Kashmir's summer capital, killing at least 10 people who had been lured to the area by a grenade explosion. The militant group Hizbul Mujahedeen, which called off a cease-fire on Tuesday, took responsibility.

Reform Party Factions Fashion Rival Tickets The Reform Party split into separate conventions in Long Beach, Calif., with Patrick J. Buchanan expected to be the nominee of one faction and John Hagelin of the other. The party's founder, Ross Perot, gave no sign of trying to mend the rift.

Rationalizing in Hollywood California Democrats who were once dismayed about Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's negative views of Hollywood now play them down or ignore them. Republicans are delighted to offer reminders that his positions on Hollywood are shared by many in the Republican Party.
Democratic officials took away a coveted speaking spot at the convention from a congresswoman who refused to cancel a fund-raiser at the Playboy mansion next week.
Bush and McCain Out West Gov. George W. Bush and Senator John McCain, who battled bitterly during the primary season, joined forces on the campaign trail.
Republican officials demanded that the major television networks devote ''not a minute more'' of air time to the Democrats' convention than they had to the Republicans'.

Bill Clinton, on His Life The president, appearing at an Illinois church with a pastor who has counseled him since 1992, talked of how his life spun out of control after an adulterous affair and how his job sometimes overwhelmed him.

Big Union Finds a Loophole The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees has used a legal loophole in creating a group that is broadcasting a television advertisement harshly critical of Gov. George W. Bush without mentioning the union's affiliation.

Ruling Against Campaign Law A federal judge threw out parts of Vermont's overhaul of campaign financing, saying the state could not impose spending limits on candidates nor limit donations from parties and from out-of-staters.

Study of Child Poverty Child poverty rates have fallen sizably in the economic boom, though they are still above the levels of 20 years ago, and more than 13 million children still live in poverty, the National Center for Children in Poverty at Columbia University said.

First Lady Recasting Image To One of the Quiet Activist In a effort to blunt criticism that she has no record to run on in her Senate campaign, Hillary Rodham Clinton, her husband and their staffs are trying to reverse the reclusive image that she projected after her failure on health care legislation. They are pressing the case that she has, in fact, been working hard behind the scenes, proposing, drafting and lobbying for legislation, appropriations and administration policy.

Wrangling Over a Successor Mayor Giuliani's top aides are deeply divided over the selection of a successor to Police Commissioner Howard Safir, with one camp arguing that the job should go to a popular insider, while others say that the mayor should choose an outsider who will shake up the force.

Man's Shooting Claims 2 Lives A man shot through the window of his car outside a downtown nightclub drove off but lost control after two blocks, the police said, and struck Jhoan Camitz, 38, a Swedish-born director of award-winning television commercials. Both men died.
Two More Missions to Mars NASA officials said they had decided to send not one but two large roving vehicles to the surface of Mars on separate missions in 2003.
Joy for a Beleaguered Yank David Cone, who had not won a game since April 28, ended his streak of 15 starts without a victory, as the Yankees beat Oakland, 12-6, at Yankee Stadium.
A Place of Her Own Jenny Thompson, who has five gold medals in Olympic team swimming, qualified for an individual event -- the 100-meter butterfly.

China Waiver for New American Yueling Chen, a recently naturalized American who was the first Chinese woman to win an Olympic gold medal in track and field, was granted a waiver by Chinese sports officials to compete in race-walking for the United States in the Olympics.

Progress in Phone Strike Verizon and its unions were said to have resolved an issue at the heart of their dispute, with the company agreeing to make it easier for the unions to organize some of the employees currently in nonunion jobs in the company's wireless division.

Shortages Hamper Tire Recall Bridgestone/Firestone's announcement that millions of tires were being recalled sent thousands of customer rushing to service centers where, in many cases, they were told that they would have to wait more than a year for replacements.

Rule on Corporate Disclosure The S.E.C. approved a rule banning companies from giving important information to analysts and professional investors before making it public. The rule is expected to accelerate the so-called democratization of investing fostered by the Net.

Deal to Sell U.S. Net Gateway Clinton administration officials were said to be close to resolving national security concerns and allowing NTT Communications of Japan to buy Verio, an American provider of Internet service.
